div.p: This paper deals with the stabilization of continuous-time Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy control systems. Based on fuzzy Lyapunov functions and nonparallel distributed compensation (non-PDC) control laws, new stabilization conditions are represented in the form of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). The theoretical proof shows that the proposed conditions can provide less conservatism than the existing results in the literature. Moreover, in order to demonstrate the effectiveness of the non-PDC control laws, the problem of H 1 controller design for T-S fuzzy systems is also studied. Simulation examples are given to illustrate the merits of the proposed methods.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: It is well known that most plants in the industry show significant nonlinearities, which usually make the analysis and controller design more difficult. In order to overcome such difficulties, various schemes have been developed in the past two decades, among which a successful approach is the fuzzy control. In recent years, Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy models [18] have become a useful tool to deal with a class of nonlinear systems. The models can represent exactly a nonlinear system with a set of linear subsystems.

The problem of stabilization for T-S fuzzy control systems has been paid much attention [2][3][4]6,7,[9][10][11][12][13][14][15][16][17][19][20][21]. The common Lyapunov function and PDC control law were proposed in [4,6,7,11,14,17,19,21] to design controllers which can stabilize the systems. Furthermore, in order to obtain more relaxed stabilization conditions, a fuzzy Lyapunov function approach was introduced in [2, 3,9,10,12,20]. However, for continuous-time T-S fuzzy systems, the fuzzy Lyapunov function will produce the time-derivatives of membership functions, and such time-derivatives will make the stability analysis more complicated [20]. In order to design a controller, upper bounds for the time-derivatives of membership functions must be considered. Since the time-derivatives are proportional to states and inputs, it is practically difficult to evaluate the upper bounds. Recently, [16] constructed a new fuzzy Lyapunov function for a class of T-S fuzzy systems, and such fuzzy Lyapunov function eliminated the requirement on the time-derivative information of the membership functions. Based on the new function, further relaxed stabilization conditions were obtained in [13,15]. However, the time-derivative information can only be eliminated under a particular premise structure of the T-S fuzzy model. Thus the new Lyapunov function cannot be applied to general T-S fuzzy systems. On the other hand, when fuzzy Lyapunov functions and PDC control law are considered, another disadvantage is that the stabilization conditions are in terms of bilinear matrix inequalities (BMIs) [16,20]. As a result, the solution to the stabilization conditions cannot be simply solved by some convex programming techniques. To overcome such problem, a non-PDC control law was presented in [12]. Furthermore, unlike the weighting-sum representation of the time-derivative information in [20], Lam and Leung [12] converted the time-derivative information into additive terms only. Recently, Mozelli et al. [15] presented a systematic approach to reduce conservativeness in stability analysis and control design for continuous-time T-S fuzzy systems, and the proposed approach was based on defining fuzzy Lyapunov functions and introducing slack matrix variables. Unlike some previous approaches based on fuzzy Lyapunov functions [16,20], the stability and stabilization conditions presented in [15] were converted into LMIs.

Based on fuzzy Lyapunov functions and non-PDC control laws, this paper is devoted to studying the stabilization of continuous-time T-S fuzzy systems. With the introduction of some slack matrix variables, new stabilization conditions are proposed in terms of LMIs. In contrast to the existing results, the obtained stabilization conditions are less conservative. Moreover, the proposed non-PDC control laws are also helpful for achieving good control effects.

This paper is organized as follows: the problem formulation and preliminaries are presented in Section 2. In Section 3, relaxed stabilization conditions are proposed based on fuzzy Lyapunov functions and non-PDC control laws. Simulation examples are provided to compare the obtained results with the existing ones in Section 4. The conclusion is given in Section 5. The proof of Theorems 9 and 14 is given in Appendixes I and II, respectively.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this paper, the stabilization problem of continuous-time T-S fuzzy systems has been studied. Based on fuzzy Lyapunov functions and non-PDC control laws, new LMI conditions involving more slack matrix variables have been obtained. Compared with the existing results concerning stabilization, the newly proposed conditions are less conservative. Simulation results illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed methods.
